headline: 'The Five' on critical race theory, celebrating 10 years

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: She kind of look like Michelle Pfeiffer.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Excuse me. What time do we get into D.C.?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's Dana, it begins with P. Dana --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. She works for George Bush.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's right. Tell me about Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Hey, Jasper, you want a treat?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: I'm going to say that is Robert Downey Junior.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
utterances.sentences: Geraldo, are you surprised that you're here?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: This guy has a late-night show. He has an exclamation point after his name.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: I don't think I've ever seen that gentleman before.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He is not a gentleman. GUTFELD I hate these people.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Could you keep your eyes on the road, please?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: What's up? How are you doing?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Very good. How do you feel about me?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: That's the guy on the news.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: The guy that used to do the man show.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: I don't know. Nice tie though.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. I really like this t-shirt. That's how I save the world. You have to buy my book. Her name is Katie --

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: I feel like I've seen her on CNN.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: CNN and the others are fake news.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: It was a horror novel by one of my favorite writers.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: I put a hell on you.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: A new show on Fox News.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's 10 years old. It's been around for 10 years, baby.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: It's on at five o'clock. What time is it now?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's five o'clock in New York City, and this is THE FIVE.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: I have not been able to muted).

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: I've been watching since I was 13. Happy birthday.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Happy birthday. That's so -- that was so well done.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I know. It was a struggle. It was 89 degrees, 100 -- with the humidity that day. I couldn't find a lot of Fox Fans out there. It was humbling.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Why didn't you go to Central Park where all the tourists are?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Dana, good point, but too late.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Do you know what I just learned though, the P.R. shots make everybody look the same, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So, it's like, that's how it goes, I think I saw her on CNN because everybody gets the same head, we call them head shots.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All the head shots look the same.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Right. They thought it was Britney Spears.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's a big -- that's a big compliment.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Geraldo, everyone knew except the one woman who thought you were the host of the Apprentice.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: You know, you can't do that show about Fox News in this the most progressive city on earth.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: You know, they voted to outlaw the army here in New York City. But, you know, they catch on and they like you and the fact that you could sell that act to them and they don't know you, I think that shows real charisma.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I was selling and act all right. Greg, we had some trouble finding people for you, we had to stay late in Union Square so you didn't feel bad that no one recognize you, but I worked hard because I didn't want to hurt your feelings.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, that's nice of you. I think -- I think what's interesting when you live in New York is the closeted fans --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- who when they see you, they give you the --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Greg, we had a few people of the show --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- did one of you on camera.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Exactly. Because they get to, this is great, and then they get fired.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It puts them in the danger, though.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And then it was like, there's people in your building who were like, in the elevator, they're like, I'm the only one in the whole building that watches your show.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I'm like, you're the tenth person that told me that this week. And I'm so glad, thank you so much.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: I have a lot of people conspiratorially saying, I like Fox News.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right. But they don't want to admit it.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: But you should've gone to Suffolk County, Trump country.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Geraldo, that's 50 minutes outside of the city.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Then you drive to Oyster Bay, that's in Nassau.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. Geraldo, you know these things. You got to go right out in the street.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You're the reverse that you could go to like Knoxville, Tennessee and do like the CNN people --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: I think they might know they just thought, they may take more of you than people --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They see the CNN people more on Fox than they see on CNN.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You should have done -- you should've gone to CHAZ if CHAZ was still here. I would've loved to see CHAZ.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: We thought that was -- we thought that CHAZ was going to last forever. Didn't it change its name?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: CHAZ. They didn't like the P.R.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I have a question. How do you get up the -- because maybe it's not courage, but I am so hesitant and reluctant to go up to anybody to ask them to talk on camera, did you just get over that right away?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I'm not afraid of rejection. So, you have to get used to a constant rejection. And I'm tall.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You're write about that in your book --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I can see people from miles away. I say, there's one.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But in your book you talk about how you rate people on how well they do in an ambush.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. We do talk about that, the best thing you can do for an ambush is not say anything. You look like it's a perp walk, but that's better than exploding like Alec Baldwin on me because that's what we want. We want people to explode.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, I love the editing. Congrats, everybody.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: A little too much on the movie scenes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. You know what, that's his last day today.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You can't -- you can't fire him. Who do you think you are?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Ahead, Democrats trying to deflect on the massive crime search as President Biden visits America's deadliest city. We'll tell you where that is.

utterances.speaker: GOV. ANDREW CUOMO (D-NY)
utterances.sentences: We went from COVID to the epidemic of gun violence. Today, the first date in the nation is going to declare a disaster emergency on nonviolence.

utterances.speaker: CUOMO
utterances.sentences: Everyone in the states, I want you to understand the extent of the problem. It then also allows us to move even faster, and free up money, and free up programs so we can get it on the street.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: OK, but you have to look at the actions that have been taken by New York City in contrast with what the governor is proposing here. In December of 2020, the New York Post had this headline, the New York City has free thousands of gun suspects this year as shootings increase in new York City. In Chicago today, or maybe it was yesterday you have the police superintendent there David Brown begging the court system to keep these guys in jail. Right? They are arresting these guys over and over again on gun charges, they're being let out, they're not being given heavy sentences. They get out, they get arrested and they're doing it all over again and people are being killed as a result. For example, 20-year-old Max Lewis who is a college student in Chicago was killed by a stray bullet that came through a subway car and killed him. There are real victims here. And so, yes, criminals are using firearms illegally to carry out their crimes, they're not being prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law to do that. And when someone like Governor Cuomo or the White House talks about implementing more gun-control laws. Laws are no good if the judicial system is not enforcing them or putting people behind bars, and criminals can't commit crimes with guns if they are in jail, and so that is the problem here.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: I get that, but there are 400 million guns more or less, Jesse, in the country. I mean, at what point is there enough, we are the number one per capita gun owners or gun possessors in the world by far.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, the Constitution says you can own one, so I guess there is no limit to gun ownership in this country. You could stop producing guns tomorrow, Geraldo, for the next 10 years we're still going to not stop the crime wave in Chicago. So, Biden's handler sent him to Chicago to talk to Lori Lightfoot about the crime surge there. He didn't go to Chicago. He went to Crystal City which is 50 miles outside of Chicago. That's the Kamala Harris route, you know, don't actually go to the border, go to the El Paso airport. He pulled the same move and it's a joke. Katie mentioned it, it's a gang problem, they have 100,000 gang members in that city.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They got the Latin kings, the gangster disciples, everyone you can think of. So, all the narcotics, the fentanyl and the meth and the heroin just flew right into Chicago because that's a hub. You look at a map, borders Indiana, Iowa, Missouri, everyone from that part of the country just goes right into Chicago gets the guns, gets the drug and they leave. So, there is a lot of money to be made and there's really no -- nothing you can do except one thing. Throw in the task force and start incarcerating these guys. Just throw the book at them. Get the federal prosecutors involved, make it a federal gun charge and lock them up because right now, all these stray bullets are killing people to the rate we haven't seen in the last 10 years. These guys don't know how to shoot weapons. These guys aren't trained shooters. They're shooting weapons all over the place. They don't know what they're doing. It's hitting people because of the population density. It's just too tight of an area to just fire bullets into the area and not expect to kill innocent people.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Law-abiding gun owners are better shots.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: But I don't think that it's hitting --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: -- it's hitting a specific target is not what they're after. What they're after is terror.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: -- and revenge. And Dana, it is about guns and drugs, that's absolutely true. We want the feds involved. Ironically today, President Biden goes to the Chicago area and two ATF agents get shot.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: One in the hand and one in the back of the head.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: -- and a Chicago cop gets shot.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: So, one thing I don't want to be a party pooper here, but Chicago didn't start when Biden got elected.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Chicago has been around. It's been rotten a long time. I went with Jim Brown to Cabrini-Green back in the 70s, Chicago has been awful for a long time. What the hell can you do about that?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Actually, my assistant had asked me the other day, she's like, well, Chicago is the worst it's ever been. I'm like, Chicago is bad and it's been bad for a while.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But in particular, let's talk about New York. So, one of the things New York wanted to do is reimagine the police. And so, they eliminated the anti-crime unit. And the anti-crime unit was basically they were smart enough and they had good intel and they were in the communities and they could be like, that guy has got illegal gun. OK, fine, we'll go pick him up. And that's how they prevent crime. They reimagine the police, they end that task force and then what happens, crime goes up. I mean, people could figure this out. As to The Washington Post giving the White House three Pinocchio's, if you could count on maybe one hand how many times in the last year The Washington Post has given a Democrat one of those things and three Pinocchio's, I don't understand why it's not four. It really should have been. But I think when the story of all this is written, is that, they not only were trying to deflect blame and lie about the Republicans, but they weren't doing anything to solve the underlying problem. Last point is, I watch one of the broadcast networks last night, and we check on another one. Two of the big broadcast networks last night did not even mention the fact, did not even mention. Didn't even a word mention not a 15-second reader that 400 people in the country were shot and 150 killed over the weekend.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Not a mention. So, it's bias by omission.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: I agree absolutely with that. And when you watch it, it's shocking how it is the different narrative, almost the different America. But you know, I read an interesting thing, Greg, about the Sandy Hook parents, they had to release, you know, the Sandy Hook parents who their six-year-olds were killed by what's his name, Lanza, Adam Lanza.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: They say there should be liability on the gun manufacturers. That when you sell a military style assault weapon, you're not selling it to deer hunters, what do you think is going to happen with the military style assault weapon.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I don't even know where to go with that question because military style assault weapon.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You mean a rifle that has a bunch of things added onto it. Look, Lori Lightfoot was asked about the criticism of her city and the crime wave and she blamed it on the fact that she is black and a lesbian. She said 99 percent of the criticism is because of that. So, this is -- this is -- a lot of this has to do with identity politics which prevents solutions. Right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: She could just totally escape culpability and go, it's not all the dead people, it's because I'm a black gay person. No, being black and being gay actually help her get elected. People gave her a lot of room to grow and instead of growing, she is dying on the vine and the city is going with it. The Democratic strategy right now is to talk about gun violence, not talk about the gun man. When you remove the person from the act, you remove your own responsibility from it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right? The elimination of responsibility also eliminates the pressure on you to do anything about it. It's gun violence, it's not the gunmen. It's not the people. We don't have to do anything about the people but we got to get these guns off the street, we need more laws. And so, gun violence falls into this weird murky stupidity of CNN where like somehow criminals don't exist, riots don't exist.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Arson doesn't exist. But these guns are walking around, these guns are walking around just shooting at people. They're not being held by anybody. It's just like how these fires mysteriously started. A fire was started.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: In a -- yes, yes. No, someone started the fire.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Unless and until people recognize that this is the civil rights issue of our time, that there is a ghetto civil war, drugs and gangs are what it's about. Unless we do something about that, we're going to be doing the story for the next 10 years.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: The head of a major teachers union ripping into parents who oppose critical race theory. See it next on THE FIVE.

utterances.speaker: RANDI WEINGARTEN, PRESIDENT, AMERICAN FEDERATION OF TEACHERS
utterances.sentences: Mark my words, our union will defend any member who gets in trouble for teaching honest history. We have a legal defense fund ready to go. Teaching the truth is not radical or wrong. Distorting history, and threatening educators for teaching the truth is what is truly radical and wrong.

utterances.speaker: WEINGARTEN
utterances.sentences: Together we can support each other because we also know there is an administration in Washington, D.C. that has our back. And an education department that truly respect your voices as professionals in classrooms. And frankly, that starts with the first lady.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That is not a hill you want to die on, critical race theory. My goodness. This country is against us by like three to one. If the CIA, Katie, were to invent a way to suddenly destroy the country it would be teaching critical race theory in our schools. Randi is not a nice woman. No Bueno, Geraldo, no Bueno. First, she's going to embezzle all the money that we gave them to not teach. I can't prove it, but I will next year when you see all the indictments because that's their track record. Then she kept all the kids out of school --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- for the entire year, and then now that they're behind, instead of catching them up, she is just dragging them through the dirty racial gutter. It's a shame, it's disgusting and the parents aren't taking it anymore. I've not seen the Democratic Party this discombobulated trying to defend something than what they're doing with critical race theory.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Usually they're really on message. Like surprisingly on message. This time they're like, we don't teach critical race theory, actually we do, we just teach it in colleges.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Actually, we just teach it in middle school but it's a good thing, but I can't define what it is, but it's good. And it's not history, Katie.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They have history class. I'm fine with teaching slavery in history that it's already taught.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They're talking about adding another topic, and it's rot.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Yes. Dana, they are gas lighting the parents and they're also calling them bullies. Let's take a listen and get your take.

utterances.speaker: WEINGARTEN
utterances.sentences: Culture worriers are labeling any discussion of race, racism, or discrimination as CRT to try to make it toxic. They are bullying teachers and trying to stop us from teaching students accurate history.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, dismissing your critics as racist is basically just a way to say that I don't have to deal with you anymore.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And it's also telling the parents you're just confused. Like, they're not and they are engaged and they've been to more school board meetings that they ever thought they would in their entire lives. Many are -- I think we showed yesterday, I think the number of school board recall petitions are up like a huge amount and then they have people deciding to run for the school board. I mean, this escalated pretty quickly from, this is just an obscure elite theory that no one really pays attention too. We have a legal defense fund in order to defend anybody --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- who is going to do it. Now here's the thing. Of all the millions of members that our teachers, there's got to be some that don't want to teach critical race theory.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And I would imagine that they are going to invite a lawsuit that will be very interesting by the time it gets to the Supreme Court what would happen. Remember, the union dues issue was already dealt with and they were pushed back on. But if you're in the union, you don't have a choice, you have to pay. So, now you are paying out of your paycheck as a teacher into the union, you don't have a choice and some of that money will be used to defend critical race theory even if you don't believe in it.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: You know, Greg, now that kids have been at home for a year, and these teachers' unions are threatening to shut down schools again in the fall, parents have been able to see more of what their kids are learning. And we saw at the beginning, they didn't want teachers -- or parents to be listening in on the Zoom calls and the meetings that the kids were having. Well, now we know why. There's -- you know, they're saying that we don't teach critical race theory. But the parents are seeing it firsthand with the work that they're doing in their home, their kitchen table.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, in fact, I mean, this is where you can really get an edge on these -- on these people because you've got to define it. And once you define it, they're on the defense because the practitioners will deny it. They'll say, oh, no CRT does this. We don't teach that. But then it's documented. It's in there. Well, we don't really do that. You don't even know what it is. But the first thing you got to realize it's a theory. It's not history, it's a theory. It's based on defining America as an oppressor versus the oppressed. It means that no one is free from race. That free -- that race, your skin color, actually defines your outcomes. And that that's the reason why we will be eternally divided. And the weirdest thing -- the worst thing about it, what makes it racist, is that it says that there are certain specific attributes that are distinctly white, all right, so that's racist. We know that's racist, and it's OK to bully a racist. That's what I've been told by the media. So, if CRT has racial components, and she's teaching this stuff, she deserves to be bullied. She should -- people, to quote the great Maxine Waters, should get in her face because she's teaching racist stuff to children. Lastly, you know what, let them run with this stuff and get your kids out of the school. It is time for a separate track, school choice. Let these people crash and burn. If they want to destroy their children, have at it. But if you're a parent, you get your kids out of there, you go to another school, you move out of town if you have to. Let these people die with what they're creating.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Yes. Now, there's this push to disconnect property taxes and money from schools and attach it directly to individuals, meaning your kids. Geraldo, you know, if you're a teacher in a school and you're teaching reading, writing, and math, that enables every student in the school to be on the same playing field when it comes to opportunity and success in life. But instead, teachers are focused on this garbage that turns kids against each other and they're bullying the parents and threatening to dox them if they dare say anything.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: I think that you're all way too sensitive. When I --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: When I was in school, the only black person in American history that I ever heard of like Jackie Robinson.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Just let me finish. Let me finish.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Let me finish. It was -- you know, the Founding Fathers and you know, I never -- I was never taught that there was only one Catholic among the signers of the Declaration of Independence. There's some good -- there's some good in 1619 and all these other concepts. They go overboard. Teachers are way too progressive.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: The parents could be insufferable too. I had lunch today --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: at Michael's great restaurant. I took my daughter and her friend Alex.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: This is all about a plug.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: both of them, you know, go to Spence.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: So, my daughter -- Sol went to Spence on the left, her friend Alex, her best friend.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What kind of tie you're wearing, Geraldo. Do you want to plug that?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: They say -- the 15-year-old say that the parents can be insufferable too. The teachers may go overboard. Let the kids figure it out.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Wait, wait, wait, I was at lunch --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Let the kids figure it out.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I was at lunch today at Arby's. Do you have a picture of me with my family?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I was at lunch at my desk.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. You ever heard of the customer is always right? Well, the parents and the students are the customers.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They're paying taxes to be taught this stuff. And if they object to it --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- then they should do something about it.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: What if you have a totally obnoxious parent who thinks something, you know -- I don't even --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You probably are the obnoxious parent.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: All right, anyway, coming up next, track star Sha'Carri Richardson will not be running in the Olympics this summer. That and more on "THE FASTEST" up next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Welcome back. Time for "THE FASTEST." First up, bad news. It's official. America's fastest woman will miss out on the Olympics this summer. Sha'Carri Richardson got suspended last week after testing positive for marijuana. And now, Team USA announced the track star did not make the final roster saying it's an issue of fairness -- I hate fairness -- for athletes who already earned a spot. I kind of understand the argument, Dana, but you're a -- from a public relations perspective, yes, could this could have been a great moment for Republicans and Democrats to come together and defended her. But they all wimped out across the board, unless I miss some people.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Or even like the U.S. Track and Field Association which finally made the ultimate decision basically to even block her from being able to run in the relay because they could have allowed her to do that because there was like a -- it's a 30 day thing. The relay isn't run until 32 days later, so they actually could have done it and been smart and let this young person do that. She said, I'm human. True, but she's super-fast human. And also, she knew the rules. I get it. But think -- just think how in shape she is. She can - - I don't know how much marijuana she smoked. I have no idea.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But she could still run faster than everybody.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I know. What do you want right now?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Jesse, let's play a game alternative universe. Trump was reelected, he would have gone to bat for her.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

Laws are no good if the judicial system is not enforcing them or putting people behind bars, and criminals can't commit crimes with guns if they are in jail, and so that is the problem here.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I get that, but there are 400 million guns more or less, Jesse, in the country. I mean, at what point is there enough, we are the number one per capita gun owners or gun possessors in the world by far.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, the Constitution says you can own one, so I guess there is no limit to gun ownership in this country. You could stop producing guns tomorrow, Geraldo, for the next 10 years we're still going to not stop the crime wave in Chicago. So, Biden's handler sent him to Chicago to talk to Lori Lightfoot about the crime surge there. He didn't go to Chicago. He went to Crystal City which is 50 miles outside of Chicago. That's the Kamala Harris route, you know, don't actually go to the border, go to the El Paso airport. He pulled the same move and it's a joke. Katie mentioned it, it's a gang problem, they have 100,000 gang members in that city.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They got the Latin kings, the gangster disciples, everyone you can think of. So, all the narcotics, the fentanyl and the meth and the heroin just flew right into Chicago because that's a hub. You look at a map, borders Indiana, Iowa, Missouri, everyone from that part of the country just goes right into Chicago gets the guns, gets the drug and they leave. So, there is a lot of money to be made and there's really no -- nothing you can do except one thing. Throw in the task force and start incarcerating these guys. Just throw the book at them. Get the federal prosecutors involved, make it a federal gun charge and lock them up because right now, all these stray bullets are killing people to the rate we haven't seen in the last 10 years. These guys don't know how to shoot weapons. These guys aren't trained shooters. They're shooting weapons all over the place. They don't know what they're doing. It's hitting people because of the population density. It's just too tight of an area to just fire bullets into the area and not expect to kill innocent people.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Law-abiding gun owners are better shots.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: But I don't think that it's hitting --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: -- it's hitting a specific target is not what they're after. What they're after is terror.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: -- and revenge. And Dana, it is about guns and drugs, that's absolutely true. We want the feds involved. Ironically today, President Biden goes to the Chicago area and two ATF agents get shot.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: One in the hand and one in the back of the head.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: -- and a Chicago cop gets shot.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: So, one thing I don't want to be a party pooper here, but Chicago didn't start when Biden got elected.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Chicago has been around. It's been rotten a long time. I went with Jim Brown to Cabrini-Green back in the 70s, Chicago has been awful for a long time. What the hell can you do about that?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Actually, my assistant had asked me the other day, she's like, well, Chicago is the worst it's ever been. I'm like, Chicago is bad and it's been bad for a while.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But in particular, let's talk about New York. So, one of the things New York wanted to do is reimagine the police. And so, they eliminated the anti-crime unit. And the anti-crime unit was basically they were smart enough and they had good intel and they were in the communities and they could be like, that guy has got illegal gun. OK, fine, we'll go pick him up. And that's how they prevent crime. They reimagine the police, they end that task force and then what happens, crime goes up. I mean, people could figure this out. As to The Washington Post giving the White House three Pinocchio's, if you could count on maybe one hand how many times in the last year The Washington Post has given a Democrat one of those things and three Pinocchio's, I don't understand why it's not four. It really should have been. But I think when the story of all this is written, is that, they not only were trying to deflect blame and lie about the Republicans, but they weren't doing anything to solve the underlying problem. Last point is, I watch one of the broadcast networks last night, and we check on another one. Two of the big broadcast networks last night did not even mention the fact, did not even mention. Didn't even a word mention not a 15-second reader that 400 people in the country were shot and 150 killed over the weekend.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Not a mention. So, it's bias by omission.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I agree absolutely with that. And when you watch it, it's shocking how it is the different narrative, almost the different America. But you know, I read an interesting thing, Greg, about the Sandy Hook parents, they had to release, you know, the Sandy Hook parents who their six-year-olds were killed by what's his name, Lanza, Adam Lanza.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: They say there should be liability on the gun manufacturers. That when you sell a military style assault weapon, you're not selling it to deer hunters, what do you think is going to happen with the military style assault weapon.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't even know where to go with that question because military style assault weapon.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You mean a rifle that has a bunch of things added onto it. Look, Lori Lightfoot was asked about the criticism of her city and the crime wave and she blamed it on the fact that she is black and a lesbian. She said 99 percent of the criticism is because of that. So, this is -- this is -- a lot of this has to do with identity politics which prevents solutions. Right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: She could just totally escape culpability and go, it's not all the dead people, it's because I'm a black gay person. No, being black and being gay actually help her get elected. People gave her a lot of room to grow and instead of growing, she is dying on the vine and the city is going with it. The Democratic strategy right now is to talk about gun violence, not talk about the gun man. When you remove the person from the act, you remove your own responsibility from it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right? The elimination of responsibility also eliminates the pressure on you to do anything about it. It's gun violence, it's not the gunmen. It's not the people. We don't have to do anything about the people but we got to get these guns off the street, we need more laws. And so, gun violence falls into this weird murky stupidity of CNN where like somehow criminals don't exist, riots don't exist.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Arson doesn't exist. But these guns are walking around, these guns are walking around just shooting at people. They're not being held by anybody. It's just like how these fires mysteriously started. A fire was started.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: In a -- yes, yes. No, someone started the fire.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Unless and until people recognize that this is the civil rights issue of our time, that there is a ghetto civil war, drugs and gangs are what it's about. Unless we do something about that, we're going to be doing the story for the next 10 years.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: The head of a major teachers union ripping into parents who oppose critical race theory. See it next on THE FIVE.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH (on camera)
utterances.utterance: The head of a top teachers union ready to go to battle to defend teaching critical race theory. AFT president Randi Weingarten slamming critics and saying her union has prepared, is prepared to fight in court to defend teachers who push it in their classrooms.

utterances.speaker: RANDI WEINGARTEN, PRESIDENT, AMERICAN FEDERATION OF TEACHERS
utterances.utterance: Mark my words, our union will defend any member who gets in trouble for teaching honest history. We have a legal defense fund ready to go. Teaching the truth is not radical or wrong. Distorting history, and threatening educators for teaching the truth is what is truly radical and wrong.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH (on camera)
utterances.utterance: And Weingarten who was with first lady Jill Biden today says the White House has her back.

utterances.speaker: WEINGARTEN
utterances.utterance: Together we can support each other because we also know there is an administration in Washington, D.C. that has our back. And an education department that truly respect your voices as professionals in classrooms. And frankly, that starts with the first lady.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH (on camera)
utterances.utterance: So, Jesse, this seems like an intimidation tactic that Ms. Weingarten is using against parents who dare to speak out. They're bringing in the lawyers, they're threatening lawsuits, and now they're saying the White House is involved.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That is not a hill you want to die on, critical race theory. My goodness. This country is against us by like three to one. If the CIA, Katie, were to invent a way to suddenly destroy the country it would be teaching critical race theory in our schools. Randi is not a nice woman. No Bueno, Geraldo, no Bueno. First, she's going to embezzle all the money that we gave them to not teach. I can't prove it, but I will next year when you see all the indictments because that's their track record. Then she kept all the kids out of school --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- for the entire year, and then now that they're behind, instead of catching them up, she is just dragging them through the dirty racial gutter. It's a shame, it's disgusting and the parents aren't taking it anymore. I've not seen the Democratic Party this discombobulated trying to defend something than what they're doing with critical race theory.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Usually they're really on message. Like surprisingly on message. This time they're like, we don't teach critical race theory, actually we do, we just teach it in colleges.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Actually, we just teach it in middle school but it's a good thing, but I can't define what it is, but it's good. And it's not history, Katie.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They have history class. I'm fine with teaching slavery in history that it's already taught.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They're talking about adding another topic, and it's rot.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes. Dana, they are gas lighting the parents and they're also calling them bullies. Let's take a listen and get your take.

utterances.speaker: WEINGARTEN
utterances.utterance: Culture worriers are labeling any discussion of race, racism, or discrimination as CRT to try to make it toxic. They are bullying teachers and trying to stop us from teaching students accurate history.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, dismissing your critics as racist is basically just a way to say that I don't have to deal with you anymore.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And it's also telling the parents you're just confused. Like, they're not and they are engaged and they've been to more school board meetings that they ever thought they would in their entire lives. Many are -- I think we showed yesterday, I think the number of school board recall petitions are up like a huge amount and then they have people deciding to run for the school board. I mean, this escalated pretty quickly from, this is just an obscure elite theory that no one really pays attention too. We have a legal defense fund in order to defend anybody --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- who is going to do it. Now here's the thing. Of all the millions of members that our teachers, there's got to be some that don't want to teach critical race theory.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And I would imagine that they are going to invite a lawsuit that will be very interesting by the time it gets to the Supreme Court what would happen. Remember, the union dues issue was already dealt with and they were pushed back on. But if you're in the union, you don't have a choice, you have to pay. So, now you are paying out of your paycheck as a teacher into the union, you don't have a choice and some of that money will be used to defend critical race theory even if you don't believe in it.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: You know, Greg, now that kids have been at home for a year, and these teachers' unions are threatening to shut down schools again in the fall, parents have been able to see more of what their kids are learning. And we saw at the beginning, they didn't want teachers -- or parents to be listening in on the Zoom calls and the meetings that the kids were having. Well, now we know why. There's -- you know, they're saying that we don't teach critical race theory. But the parents are seeing it firsthand with the work that they're doing in their home, their kitchen table.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, in fact, I mean, this is where you can really get an edge on these -- on these people because you've got to define it. And once you define it, they're on the defense because the practitioners will deny it. They'll say, oh, no CRT does this. We don't teach that. But then it's documented. It's in there. Well, we don't really do that. You don't even know what it is. But the first thing you got to realize it's a theory. It's not history, it's a theory. It's based on defining America as an oppressor versus the oppressed. It means that no one is free from race. That free -- that race, your skin color, actually defines your outcomes. And that that's the reason why we will be eternally divided. And the weirdest thing -- the worst thing about it, what makes it racist, is that it says that there are certain specific attributes that are distinctly white, all right, so that's racist. We know that's racist, and it's OK to bully a racist. That's what I've been told by the media. So, if CRT has racial components, and she's teaching this stuff, she deserves to be bullied. She should -- people, to quote the great Maxine Waters, should get in her face because she's teaching racist stuff to children. Lastly, you know what, let them run with this stuff and get your kids out of the school. It is time for a separate track, school choice. Let these people crash and burn. If they want to destroy their children, have at it. But if you're a parent, you get your kids out of there, you go to another school, you move out of town if you have to. Let these people die with what they're creating.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes. Now, there's this push to disconnect property taxes and money from schools and attach it directly to individuals, meaning your kids. Geraldo, you know, if you're a teacher in a school and you're teaching reading, writing, and math, that enables every student in the school to be on the same playing field when it comes to opportunity and success in life. But instead, teachers are focused on this garbage that turns kids against each other and they're bullying the parents and threatening to dox them if they dare say anything.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I think that you're all way too sensitive. When I --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: When I was in school, the only black person in American history that I ever heard of like Jackie Robinson.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Just let me finish. Let me finish.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Let me finish. It was -- you know, the Founding Fathers and you know, I never -- I was never taught that there was only one Catholic among the signers of the Declaration of Independence. There's some good -- there's some good in 1619 and all these other concepts. They go overboard. Teachers are way too progressive.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: The parents could be insufferable too. I had lunch today --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: at Michael's great restaurant. I took my daughter and her friend Alex.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This is all about a plug.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: both of them, you know, go to Spence.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: So, my daughter -- Sol went to Spence on the left, her friend Alex, her best friend.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What kind of tie you're wearing, Geraldo. Do you want to plug that?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: They say -- the 15-year-old say that the parents can be insufferable too. The teachers may go overboard. Let the kids figure it out.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Wait, wait, wait, I was at lunch --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Let the kids figure it out.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I was at lunch today at Arby's. Do you have a picture of me with my family?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I was at lunch at my desk.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. You ever heard of the customer is always right? Well, the parents and the students are the customers.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They're paying taxes to be taught this stuff. And if they object to it --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- then they should do something about it.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: What if you have a totally obnoxious parent who thinks something, you know -- I don't even --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You probably are the obnoxious parent.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: All right, anyway, coming up next, track star Sha'Carri Richardson will not be running in the Olympics this summer. That and more on "THE FASTEST" up next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Welcome back. Time for "THE FASTEST." First up, bad news. It's official. America's fastest woman will miss out on the Olympics this summer. Sha'Carri Richardson got suspended last week after testing positive for marijuana. And now, Team USA announced the track star did not make the final roster saying it's an issue of fairness -- I hate fairness -- for athletes who already earned a spot. I kind of understand the argument, Dana, but you're a -- from a public relations perspective, yes, could this could have been a great moment for Republicans and Democrats to come together and defended her. But they all wimped out across the board, unless I miss some people.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Or even like the U.S. Track and Field Association which finally made the ultimate decision basically to even block her from being able to run in the relay because they could have allowed her to do that because there was like a -- it's a 30 day thing. The relay isn't run until 32 days later, so they actually could have done it and been smart and let this young person do that. She said, I'm human. True, but she's super-fast human. And also, she knew the rules. I get it. But think -- just think how in shape she is. She can - - I don't know how much marijuana she smoked. I have no idea.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But she could still run faster than everybody.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I know. What do you want right now?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Jesse, let's play a game alternative universe. Trump was reelected, he would have gone to bat for her.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, she hit a blonde. She's fast. It wasn't crack. Put her on the track. I pardon her. I pardon her.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Perfect. That's exactly what would I --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I want to see her run. America wants to see her run.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We probably did call for it, Geraldo.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I actually got -- it never made me run faster.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Actually, you know, I used to be on the board of the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws. That was 1972. We thought it would be illegal by 73, 74, 75. And look, it's just taking so long. And this is just another tragic story. another victim of reefer madness.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I think that as long as men are allowed to compete in the Olympics as women --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: That women should be allowed to dope.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's true. It's true. It's true.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: All women should be allowed to dope.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We should have -- we should have like a separate race.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But like we could host a competition.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I was wondering where you were going.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Everybody gets high? It's a high race.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes. And see how fast everybody can run. Oh my gosh, I want to sponsor this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Hey, Dud, that 100 meters, the 11th year of THE FIVE. It was a good run.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It was a good year. Our first thing was to get high and --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right, up next men are going through a friendship crisis. A new survey says one in five males don't have a close friend. And the percentage of men with at least close -- six close friends that fallen by half since the early 90s. Jesse, I pretended it's because they all died.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, I did radio interviews to promote How I Save the World. And everybody asked me, do you hang out with Greg off-camera? And I say the same thing every time. Our parents won't let us play together. We could be best friends, but it's not allowed.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That is so funny. I haven't thought about that in a while. But my mom used to say that to me all the time. And I bet other mothers said it to their kids. Like, Geraldo, were you a my mom will let me play with you kind of kid.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Old men -- old men don't have friends. They're friends with their wives' husbands.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I mean, their wives' husband friend.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I was going to say that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh my God. And it's like, you don't have any choice in it.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You know, your friends are either dead or they're way separated.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Then you have to make an effort. You have to make an effort.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Women are very good at this. They make the effort. They have a lot of friends. And like --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You have to -- and if you're out there and your husband is like, maybe not having as many friends as you'd like, you got to push a little bit. Like, set up a date.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, I just think we should have a separate race. We'll be right back. No, Katie, what -- so you -- do you buy this? Does your husband have a lot of friends.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: My husband is like the mayor of the world. He will be in the middle of nowhere in an airport and he knows somebody. So, we're the opposite. He has a lot of friends.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: He just knows a lot of people, has a lot of friends. But I do feel sorry for the guys who don't have a lot of friends. I think it's -- the rise of technology has limit people's circle.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what, we -- you should look at it a different way. Make enemies as you get older. That's more fun, right?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: My wife's friends are obviously her age, much younger than I am, so their husbands are much younger than I, so it's kind of --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I started texting all my surviving friends.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right, that's upbeat. Pictures of his dead friends with Geraldo. That's next. Up next, Jesse has a special Feeding Frenzy and it might make us squirm.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Welcome back, everybody. So, over the last few months, I've become reacquainted with baby food. And that inspired me to put together a very special feeding frenzy. I made a tasty little selection of three top-notch baby foods. Of course, it's all organic. And you guys are going to test these out and we're going to figure out the flavor. So, let's begin. So, food one is the green one. Everybody raise your spoon.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Tell us what this flavor is, Greg.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Celery, close. It's not celery but you're in the right --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wrong. Can we get a buzzer?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I know what -- it's like that thing on Thanksgiving.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Green bean casserole. Geraldo, you actually have to eat it.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I just did it. It's kind of like --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And by the way, Geraldo, when he looks at the plate, he goes where's the food? He thought these were dips.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I thought it was the sauce.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I like that we all get separate spoons for this. Like, this is totally professional.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And also, look how much is in there. I'm like, who's going to eat this?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Bottoms up, Perino. It's a shot. All right, next one. It is the mustard-colored flavor.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: This is what you take out of the diaper.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh good reaction shots. The cameramen are doing a great job.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: We have to do another one to figure this out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No. Come on, guys. This is easy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, it looks like butternut squash.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No. You guys are terrible at this. Guys, it's chicken noodle.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Geraldo, I don't even think you tried it.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I did. I did. It's on my tongue.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This is revenge for all those TV shows you did in the 80s and you forced us to --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I've got it in my mustache.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's a lot in there. all right, we're going to finish up with the third baby food and it's dark.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: This one looks like the best.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It looks like a one, but it's not.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I know this one. I requested this one.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: It tastes like a fig newton.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: It is kind of fig newton.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know how I feel.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But if I have a terrible show after this, I'm blaming you.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Well, you're spending a lot of time in a certain room.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh. I just ate the whole thing. Wow.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You ate the whole thing, prunes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Let's bring out someone very special.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: It's Emma! Hey, and the baby.

utterances.speaker: EMMA WATTERS, WIFE OF JESSE WATTERS
WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, what does the shirt say?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Look at the big boy. Look at the big boy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm Watters and this is my world.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
